  protected val component: C by lazy { createComponent() }


  protected abstract fun createComponent() : C

Why do you think it should work?
You’re trying to pass an instance of wrong type to a method.
it isn’t wrong type, it is a class that implements MvpView
And? Does it make this class `V`?
it makes it fit into V: MvpView
No, it doesn’t.
`BaseActivity<SomeMvpView, SomeMvpPresenter, SomeMvpComponent>`
Obviously, `BaseActivity` is not necessary `SomeMvpView`.

No, it doesn’t.

`BaseActivity<V implements MvpView, SomeMvpPresenter, SomeMvpComponent>` implements MvpView
It doesn’t mean this class is `V`. It doesn’t implement `V`.
`V` is just a class that implements `MapView`, but a different one possibly.
<@U0K1ALDQE>: You can see the same answer in the kotlinlang Slack channel :simple_smile:
And that’s not my answer.

>`V` is just a class that implements `MapView`, but a different one possibly.
Yeah, true. :thumbsup:
Can some1 explain that to me? ><

if it was
`BaseActivity<MvpView, SomeMvpPresenter, SomeMvpComponent>` it would work, because BaseActivity implements MvpView and obeys it’s contracts
but BaseActivity can’t implement a generic interface with an unknown contract, thus it can’t obey it and satisfy the V extends MvpView
right
so if V had a method “getToTheBar(foo: Foo)”, base activity wouldn’t implement it and would be breaking the contract
thanks <@U0RGXBYUD> , couldn’t exactly wrap my head around it until now :thumbsup:

interface MVPPresenter<V : MVPView> {


  abstract fun attachView(view: V)




  abstract fun detachView()

text: MVPPresenter<V> —> but V implements MVPView
so attachView takes a parameter of type MVPView
No?
If I change `  abstract fun attachView(view: MVPView)` it works, but I don’t want that. (right?)
No :simple_smile:
`attachView` accepts `V`, which is `MvpView` but it’s not necessary `MvpBaseActivity`.
but `MVPBaseActivity` implements MvpView
If you make `attachView` accept `MvpView` then everything will work fine. But why do you need `V` then?

`ArrayList` implements `List` and `LinkedList` implements `List` too. But `ArrayList` is not `LinkedList`.
